projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

div.p: BIBLIOTHECA SCHOLASTICA INSTRVCTISSIMA. OR, A Treasurie of ancient Adagies, and sententious Prouerbes, selected out of the English, Greeke, Latine, French, Italian and Spanish. Ranked in Alphabeticall order, and suited to one and the same sense. PVBLISHED, By THOMAS DRAXE Batch. in Diuinitie.

figure.figDesc: printer's device of John Bill, featuring an old man standing by a olive-tree with falling branches (McKerrow 349)

div.head: CELSISSIMO ILLVSTRISSIMO QVE Principi CAROLO, Duci Eboracensi, & potentissimi IACOBI, Magnae BRITANNIAE, GALLIAE, HIBERNIAE, & adjacentium Insularum Regis filio vnico, salutem sempiternam.
div.p:
QVantum & quàm insignem (Princeps nobilissime) ornatum & splendorem, artibus, eloquentiae, rationi & orationi accersant & afferant graves paroemiae, aureae{que} sententiae proverbiales, potest, inter caetera, cuivis intelligenti existimatori, ex intimaearum antiquitate, admirabili dignitate, eleganti venustate & vsibus illustribus constare, & demonstrari, Et mihi astipulantes, imò acclamantes, habeo omnes 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , & nominatim, summos & celeberrimos illos viros, Erasmum illum Roterodamensem, Hadrianum Iunium, Iosephum Scaligerum, Ioannem Alexandrum Brassicanum, Polydorum Virgilium, Gilbertum cognatum, Claudium illum Minoim, Iohannem Vlpium, Iohannem Schoderum, Ianum Gruterum, Drusium
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ; aliosque complures, de bonis literis optimè meritos, qui Adagia, Latina, Graeca, Rabbinica, Anglica, Germanica, Hispanica & Italica in suas distinctas classes, serie alphabetica contulerunt, & ad artem revocârunt.

Verùm enimverò, quum, in dialecticis, (prout maximè rarus ille, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , illuminatissimus, & beatissimus Martyr, Petrus Ramus probat) artificialia argumenta
testimonijs quae sunt argumentum inartificiale, sive minus artis habens praeponderent, quumque ex minimis maxima, ex culmo spica, exvitibus & uvis vindemia, & ex primitijs vniversamessis aestimetur & cognoscatur, placuit de suprà commemoratis proverbiorum laudibus nonnihil proponere.

Positum igitur imprimis sit, quod Adagiorum antiquitas evincitur, non tam ex priscorum philosophorum Symbolis, quorum integra fermè philosophia in paroemijs involuta videretur, quàm ex sacris Scripturis, in quibus passim occurrunt, & quae suâ primogenia vetustate, omnia alia scripta longissimè praecedunt. Huc aàdatur etiam quòd, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ille & sapientissimus Solomon, tria proverbiorum millia conscripsisse dicitur, quorum magnam partem eximius ille parabolarum liber complectitur. Deinde, Adagiorum dignitas, auctoritas, & quasi 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 hinc dignoscitur & agnoscitur, quod non modò splendore, & celebritate florentissimi, philosophi, oratores, poetae & historici gentiles, verbi gratia, Aristoteles, Aristides, Chrysippus, Cicero, Diogenianus, Ouidius, Plato, Plautus, Plutarchus, Suidas, Terentius, Theophrastus, Varro, Virgilius &c. verum etiam veteres illi, & verè venerabiles primaenae ecclesiae patres, nempe, Chrysostomus, Hieronymus, Tertullianus, &c. ea valdè frequentârunt & suis scriptis, tamquam tot Cimelia admiscuerunt.
Quinimo, Christus Iesus, salutis nostrae reparator & vindex, ab eorum vsu non abhorruit.

Omnium concessu confirmatum est, quòd in quotidiano sermone, principiorum 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 pondus, & oraculorum vim obtinent, adeò vt his (semper autem rudia, ridicula & impia proverbia meritissmò reijcio) facilè acquiescamus.

Tertiò, in dictionibus, scriptionibus, epistolis, orationibus, eximiam pulchritudinem, singularémque venustatem habent, quippe, temperatè & tempestiuè vsurpata, sunt quasi tot annulares gemmae palis affabrèilligatae & inclusae: tot eleganter spectabiles limbi vestibus subassuti; tot nitidissimae stellulae sermonem nostrum collustrantes, & tanquam tot reticula florida naribus mirificè abblandientia.

Quartò & postremò, varios & commodissimos vsus habent. Namque (quemadmodum Aristotelem autorem habemus) veteris philosophiae reliquias nobis praegustandas propinant, sunt ingenij cotes, dotes, & indices: sunt vitae ordinandae norma & amussis: vitia humana non tam salse & scitè, quàm cum auctoritate quadam exagitant: sunt memoriae subsidia & promptuaria: declamaturis & subitò dicturis amplum & aptum è re nata sermonis apparatum auditoribus accommodatum, subministrant: perturbatum & deiectum animum, à luctu ad laetitiam, ex inopinato, traducunt: orationem nostram, allegoricè, ironicè, metaphorice & hyperbolicè enunciatis voculis, decorant & exornant. Deni{que} (ne innumerabilia consecter) & epistolae modulum excedam, optimis & classicis auctoribus perappositè subserviunt.

Quae cum ita se habeant, ego (quantumuis neglectus) scholasticis & studiosis prodesse cupiens, praestantiora Adagia, Anglica, addo, & multa Gallica & Hispanica, & aliquot Italica, Britannicè reddita selogi, & ad artem ordinemque redegi, illisque eodem spectantia, sensúque congrua, multa millena Latina, Graeca & nonnulla Rabbinica prouerbia, ex probatissimis scriptoribus excerpta & excepta operosè, & subsecivis horulis, subiunxi.

Et quandoquidem (Princeps excellentissime) tuis regijs studijs (non obstante hoc, quòd ab exquisito & perpolito
artifice, Domino Thoma Murraio, fideliter & foeliciter erudiris) ea aliquid adiumenti allatura confido, & quoniam ipse fratri tuo non ita pridem in coelum suscepto, Henrico, principi summae expectationis & incomparabili virtute, celeriter succrescis, & quum sis vera & viua Patris tui serenissimi & Regalibus laudibus eminentissimi Regis Iacobi, proles & imago, eiusque virtutes imiteris, hunc igitur ingenioli mei foetum tuae Celsitudini quàm demississimè do, dico, dedico, offero, & eadem operâ, tuae Excellentiae candorem emprecatus, & offensionem deprecatus, hîc excurrentis praefationis epilogum, observantiae verò exordium pono. Deus Opt. Max. Rex Regum, & Dominus dominantium, tuam Celsitudinem longaevam & pancraticam reddat, te defendat ab omni malo, & inducat in omne bonum, externum, internum, & aeternum. Amen.

closer.dateline: E tutissima & celeberrima navium statione Harwicensi, in agro Essexiensi. Iulij 30. 1615.
closer.signed: Tuae Celsitudinis obseruantissimus, THOMAS DRAXVS, Ecclesia Douercourtiensis & Harwichiensis Minister.

list.head: ¶ Abilitie, or power.

item.hi: Man must cut his coat according to his cloth.
Where coyne is not common, commons must be scant.
Who that may not as they will, must will as they may.

list.item: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . id est, Dementiae est suprà vires aliquid facere.
Quisque debet se suo pede moduloque metiri. H r.
Tecum habita & nôris quam sit tibi curta supellex. Horat.
Fiat moderatè quod faciendum est saepius.
Viuendum homini non vt lubet, sed vt licet. Terent.
Si res tua non sufficiat tibi, tu fac vt ei sufficias.
Dum non licet vt expeto, viuo vt queo. Terent.
Rebus & in censu si non est quod fuit antè. Cato.
Fac viuas contentus eo quod tempora praebent.
Si bouem non possis, asinum agas. Suidus.

item.hi: Hee beginneth to build to soone that hath not money to finish it.
Building is chargeable.

list.item: Efficimus pro nostris viribus maenia. Plaut.
Quum facis domum, ne relinquas impolitam. Hesiod.
Non faciendus sumptus maior quam res patitur. Cic.
Quum non possit fieri quod vie, id velis quod possis. Terent.

Nisi aestimatis viribus non est aggrediendum negotium.
Parvum parva decent.
Tentanda non sunt, quae non possint effici.
Oportet agrum imbecilliorem esse quam agricolam. Columell.
Non plus occupari debet quâm cui sufficere possimus. Senec. Epist. 1. lib. 19.

item.hi: A man must not roame aboue his reach.

list.item: Fortunam debet quisque manere suam. Ouid.
Intra tuam pelliculam te contine. Porphyr.
Onus cui impar sis ne subiveris.
Aut minus animi, aut plus potentiae. Plutarc.
Sine pennis volare haud facilè est. Plaut.
Non captandum quod capi non potest.
Noli affectari quod tibi non est datum. Plaut.

list.head: ¶ Absence.

item.hi: A man knoweth not the worth of a thing before that he wanteth it.
He is an ill husband that is not missed.

list.item: Carendo magis quàm ferendo, nos bona nostra intelligimus. Cicero.
Plures amant amicos, cum sunt mortui.
Quid sanitas boni habet, languor indicat.

item.hi: Long absent, soone forgotten.
Out of sight, out of minde.

list.item: Qui procul ex oculis, procul est à limine cordis.

item.hi: When the Cat is away, the Mice play.

list.item: Nihil rectè faciunt ministri nisi adsit herus.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . i. Ovium nullus vsus si pastor abest.

list.head: ¶ Absurdities.

item.hi: Hee seeketh to catch an Hare with a taber.
He goeth the wrong way to worke, or to the wood.
To fright a bird is not the way to catch her.
Then we shall catch birds to morrow.

list.item: Nihil inuenitur quod sua via non quaeritur. Quintil.
Claue findit ligna, & securi fores aperit. Plutarch.

item.hi: He would build castles in the ayre.
He hath crotchets in his head.

list.item:
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .
id est, per totam vitam inani spe abundat.

item.hi: As fine as an ape in purple.
Honour is vnseemely for a foole.
As meet as a sow to beare a saddle.

list.item: Maximum imperium est imperito maximum dedecus.
Loco ignominiae est apud indignum dignitas. Syrus.
Annulus aureus in naribus suis. Prou. 11.
Honor indignis habitus, non est honos, sed onus.
Caput artis decere quod facias. Quintil.
In toga saltantis personam induit. Mart.

item.hi: A great shooe will not fit a little foot.

list.item: Herculis cothurnus non aptus infanti. Quintil.
Calceus ne sit pede maior. Luc.
Vt mihi res, sic me rebus submittere cogor. Hor. de arte Poetica.

item.hi: He setteth the cart before the horses.
Kim kam, arsie versie.

list.item: Smaragdus in luce obscurus, noctu lucidus. Plin.
Occant prius, semper quàm sarriunt rustici. Plaut.

item.hi: Hee would binde Beares.

list.item: Durum est contendere cum victore. Hor.
Clavam extorqueret è manu Herculis. Horat.
Aut plus potentiae, aut minus animi.
Cum Dijs gigantum more pugnat. Cicer.

item.hi: He kicketh against the prickes.
He striveth against the streame.
The Sunne, Moone, and the seuen Stars are against him.

list.item: Aduersus stimulum calcat. Actes Apost. c. 9.
Invitâ Mineruâ, dicit & facit omnia. Cic.
Heu, nihil inuitis fas quenquam fidere diuis. Virg.
Quod natura negat, nemo faeliciter audet.
Si stimulos pugnis caedis, tuae manus plus dolet. Plaut.

item.hi: He cannot see wood from trees.
As blinde as a beetle.
If it were a Beare, it would bite him.
Which way to London? a poke full of plummes.
Hee commeth in with his fiue egges, whereof foure of then are addle, or rotten.

list.item: Alia Menocles, alia porcellus loquitur. Lucilius.
Ego rogo de alliis, tu respondes de Cepis.

item.hi: Of a mole-hill, hee maketh a mountaine.

list.head: ¶ Abuse.

item.hi: God asketh corne, and the Deuill marreth the sacke.
God sendeth meat, and the Deuill sendeth Cookes.

list.item: Benè agit Deus, vtcunque malè agant instrumenta.
Nullum bonum est, quo quis malè non vtatur.

list.head: ¶ Aduancement.

item.hi: Hee is highly aduanced.
The world is somewhat amended with him.

list.item: Melius quàm heri, cras fortasse, melius habebit. Aristoph.
A scapha in triumphalem quadrigam. Syne.

list.head: ¶ Aduenturing.

item.hi: Hee shall neuer haue a thing good cheape, that is afraid to aske the price.
Nothing venture, nothing haue.
Spare to speake, spare to speed.
Faint heart neuer wanne faire Ladie.

list.item: Audendum aliquid, si vis esse aliquid.
Magnum & memorabile facinus non fit abs{que} periculo. Ter.
Qui timidè rogat, docet negare. Sen.
In iudicio, saepe homines impedit pudor.
Petentis negligentia reprehenditur, vbi de dantis mis • recordia non dubitatur. Chrysost.

item.hi: A man may holde his peace in an ill time.

list.item: Est tempus loquendi, & tempus silendi. Eccles. 3.

item.hi: An hooke well lost to get a Salmon.

list.item: Damna parua nonnunquam magni lucri sunt causa. Greg. 3 mor.
Pecuniam in loco negligere, interdum maximum est lucrum.

item.hi: Many ventures make a full fraught.
Many hands make light worke.

list.item: Duobus pariter euntibus fiducia maior. Cic.
Quae non prosunt singula, multa iuvant.
Non sunt contemnenda quasi parua, sine quibus magna esse non possunt.
Si parvum parvo addideris, tandem magnus fiet cumulus. Hes.

item.hi: A man must not be too venturous.
It is good to be merry, and wise.

list.item: Fortitudo quae deinde in nervum crumpit, ferrea est. Teren.
Omnis actio debet temeritate carere. Cic.
Haud temere summa rerum est danda in aleam. Liu.
Casus hoc minus experiundus, quo vicisti saepius.

list.head: ¶ Aduersitie, or misery.

item.hi: There is not so great a stood, but there is as low an ebbe.
There is no hill without his valley.

list.item: Vt l • psu grauiore cadant. Lucan.

item.hi: A friend is neuer knowen vntill a man haue need of him.

list.item: A quibus ameris, sola paupertas ostendit.
In pace vires nemo cognoscit suas.
Amicus certus re incerta cernitur. Cic.
Sorte patet miserâ quae sit dilectio vera.
Amicos res optimae parant, adversae probant.
Vis experiri amicum, calamitosus fias? Varr.

item.hi: Out of the hall into the Kitchen.
Out of Gods blessing into the warme Sunne.

list.item: De toga ad pallium transijt. Tert.
In seruitutem de regno cadere graue est. Sen.
Ipsus Orestes modo fuit rex, modo mendicus factus est.
Nihil est tam miserabile, quàm ex beato effici miser.

item.hi: A poet in Aduersitie, can hardly make verses.

list.item: Quis virtutem amplectitur ipsam praemia si tollas?

Quae contemnuntur, jacent. Cic.
In Aduersitie men finde eies.
—Grande doloris
Publica vi • tuti per mala facta via est. Quid.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . i. quae nocent docent.
Nunquam sapiunt multi nisi in angustiis.

list.head: Affection, or fancie.

item.hi: Affection is blinde.
Fancie is a foole.
Affection blindeth reason.
Loue is a partiall Iudge.

list.item: Aeger animus falsa pro veris videt.

item.hi: Affections are the wings of the soule.

list.head: ¶ Ambition.

item.hi: The greatest state is the lesse sure.
Looke not to hie, lest a chip fall into thine eie,
The higher that the tree is, the greater is his fall.
Hie windes blow on hie places.
The higher that I clime, the greater is my fall.

list.item: Magnus ex alto culmine lapsus. Sen.
Simul profecto premere faelices Deus, cum caepit, vrget.
Maior fortuna, minus secura est. Sen.
Quae repente attolluntur, non sunt diuturna.

Fulmen alta petit, non humiles casas.
— grauiore casu
Decidunt turres feriunt{que} summos fulmina montes. Hor.
Summa ad imum dilabūtur promptius quàm ascenderunt.

item.hi: Hee that mounteth higher then hee ought, falleth lower then he would.
Pride will haue a fall.

list.item: Citò ignominia fit superbi gloria. Syrus.
Sequitur superbos vltor a tergo Deus. Sen.

item.hi: The higher mountaine the greater descent.

list.item: Plerumque altis & excelsis adiacent abrupta. Plin. epist. 26. lib. 9.
Quicquid effertsors in altum, effert, vt mox ruat.
Ipse Orestes, modò suit Rex, modò mendicus.
Occasus vicinus est, vbi non est incremento locus.
Aut euertit fortuna domos. Sen. in Hippol.
Nulli diuturna & magna contingunt bona. Sen.

item.hi: The rising of one man is the falling of another.

list.item: Vnius praelatio est alterius contumelia. Tertull.
Generatio vnius est corruptio alterius. Arist.

item.hi: New Lords, new Lawes.
Many Lords many lawes.

list.item: Nec quenquam iam ferre potest Caesarue priorem, Pompeiusue parem.
Auxilia legum non valent sub ambitu.
Crebra vsui regno, nulli est mutatio. Tacitus.
Ratio imperii Constat, si vni redditur.
Discordiae remedium est ab vnico rege. Tacitus.
Omnis mutatio mala est, nisi in malo.
Vbi regnant plures, ibi nemo imperat.

item.hi: He shall neuer clime higher.
He is at the highest round of the ladder of promotion.

list.item: Faelicitas cum nequit procedere, recedit. Paterculus lib. 1. c. 17.
Vela inflata notis secundis ventos praetiment Sen.
Quod repente attollitur, non est diuturnum.
Non habet locum incrementi quicquid ad summum peruenit. Sen.
Non ad vltimum exit nisi lenta faelicitas. Sen ad Martiam.

item.hi: Poore and proud, fie, fie.
A Lords heart, and a beggars purse agree not.
Iacke would bee a gentleman, if hee could speake French.

list.item: Inops potentem dum vult imitari perit.
Sub vili veste, saepe fastus hospitat.
Si vix toleratur diues superbus, pauperem superbum quis feret? Ambros.
Non oportet superbum esse, hominem servum.
Nemo debet gloriari nisi de suo.

item.hi: There is no accord, where euery man would be a Lord.
Loue and lordship abide no fellowship.
Loue and royaltie suffer no equall,

list.item: Plus vno imperatore in bello esse, malum est.
Multorum imperiis geri non potest respub. bene.
Ad simultatem nihil tam pronum quam aemulatio.
Nunquam est fidelis cum potente societas. Ouid.
Non bene cum sociis regna Venusque manent.

Non benè conueniunt, nec in
vna sede morantur

list.head: ¶ Amendment.

item.hi: He goeth farre who neuer turneth,
It is neuer too late to doe well.
He is yong enough to amend.
It is better late then neuer.
A shrewd boy maketh a good man.

list.item: Nunquam sera est ad bonos mores via. Sen.
Schola cuiusque ordinis homines admittit. Qu • nt.
Siquis calle malo fuerit, festinet ab i • lo.
Non errat penitùs, faciens in calle regressum.
Serò meliùs quàm nunquam ad recta vertitur.
Multi adolescentes è vitiis emerserunt, & se ad bonam f • ugem receperunt. Cic.
Rectae voluntati, esse serum nihil potest.
Omnia sperat, omnia credat charitas. 1. Cor. 13.17.

item.hi: A fault, and an amends.

list.item: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . i. Beneficia in praesenti tempore obliuionem inducunt, eorū quae priùs malè acta sunt.
Vix is deliquit, qui dilictum corrigit.
Optimus portus peccatori est consilij mutatio.
Criminis medicina princeps, est ipsa poenitentia.
Quem poenitet peccare penè est innocens. Rupertus.

item.hi: The best may amend.

list.item: Nemo est probus quem poenitet quam sit probus.
Bonum bono additum facit ipsum melius. Aristot.
Nullum inuenire est, in quo carpere sit nihil.

list.head: ¶ Anger.

item.hi: He that is angry, is not at ease.
The angry man neuer wanteth woe.
Hee that is angry without a cause, must be pleased without an amends.

list.item: Ira cruditas mentes praeterlabitur. Arbitr. Satyric.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , i. insanimus omnes cum irascimur.
Omnes alios affectus ira sibi subijcit.
Pessimus auctor rerum gerendarum ira. Seneca.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . i. ira multos facere cogit mala.
Irati mediocritatem illam inter nimium & parum, non retinent Cic.
Nunquam sine tormento sui magnus motus irae.
Ingentis irae exitus furor est. Sen. Epist. 6. lib. 12.

item.hi: At three words, he is at the top of the house.
Little pot, soone hote.
He is as sharpe as a thorne.
Snap-straw.
Hee is too hastie to be a Parish Priest.

list.item: Iram gerere in promptu insipientis est. Plaut.
Nunquam absque tormento sui fuit violentus motus.
Iram gerere in promptu est merae insipientiae.
Tetigit lapidem à cane morsum. Plin.
Litem movebit, si vel asinus canem momorderit. Plut.
Quantulacun{que} adeò est, occasio sufficit irae.
Pro leuibus noxis plumbeas iras gerit. Senec.

item.hi: All his dishes are chaffing-dishes.

list.item: Apud sc non est prae iracundia. Terent.

list.head: ¶ Apparell.

item.hi: Many birds haue glorious plumes.
Faire feathers make faire foules.
Apparell maketh a man.
Apparell shapeth both man and beast.

list.item: Pluma tegit volucres, ouibus sua lana decora est.
Hunc decorant homines quem vestimenta decorant.
Quod virtus & pulchritudo non potest, vestis obtinet.
Cultus & magnificus incessus addit hominibus auctoritaté. Quin.
In vili cultu nemo tractatur honestè.

item.hi: His body is better clothed then his soule.
The Peacocke hath faire feathers, but soule feete.
Faire without, but foule within.

list.item: Stultissimus est qui hominem ex vestibus aestimat.
Cura cui est magna cultus, ei magna virtutis incuria est. Marcell. lib. 16. c. 5.

list.head: ¶ Armour.

item.hi: He that hath a staffe, may beat away a knaue.
A good sword will stand one in stead.

list.item:
Absque baculo ne incedito.
An asse.

item.hi: If all men may say that thou art an asse, then bray.

list.item: Nec aures habeo nec tango, Hiero.
A Babbler wearieth all the company.

item.hi: Many speake much, who cannot speake well.
Where many words are, the truth often goeth by.
Much babling is not without offence.
A foole is knowne by much babling.

list.item: Percontatorem fugito, nam garrulus idem est. Hor.
Deficit auditor, non deficit, ille loquendo.
Tum loquentur lusemiae quum tacebunt graculi.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . i. effraeni oris.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . i. linguae ambulachrum est loquacitas.
Nunquam tacet quem morbus loquendi tenet. Sen.

list.head: ¶ Backebiting.

item.hi: A false tongue will hardly speake trueth.
To speake euill of others, is the fist Element.

list.item: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . i. Citiùs carpent quàm aemulabuntur.
Impijs est voluptas alienam famam laedere.

Calumniatoris est in crimen vocare omnia, nihil probare.
Malè de te loquuntur homines,
nesciunt benè loqui. Senec.
Quaestui stultis habetur malè loqui de melioribus.

list.head: ¶ Bashfulnes, or blushing.

item.hi: Bashfulnesse is a signe of grace.
Bashfulnesse is the blush of vertue.

list.item: Illum perijsse dico, cui perijt pudor. Plaut.
Culpam minuit pudor, cumulat defensio. Ambr.
Vultus pudentis, etiam sermonis loco est.
Bona est timiditas quae nos deterret a vitijs.
Sine verecundià nihil est rectum. Cic.

item.hi: Pannes may blot, but they cannot blush.

list.item: Dicere quae puduit, scribere iussit amor. Ouid.

list.head: ¶ Beginning.

item.hi: A good beginning maketh a good end.
Like beginning like ending.
He that soweth good seede, shall reape good corne.
A good winter bringeth a good Summer.

list.item: Dimidium facti qui bene caepit, habet.

item.hi: A shrewd boy maketh a good man.

list.item: Vix quisquam transit in bonum nisi ex malo. Pub. Syrus.

item.hi: Let him that beginneth the song make an end.

list.item: Tute hoc intristi, tibi tutum est comedendum. Plaut. Terent.
Faecem bibet qui vinum bibit. Aristoph.

item.hi: Euery thing hath a beginning.
Rome was not built in a day.
A man must creepe before that he can goe.
A man must begin before that hee can make an end.
Euery thing hath his seed.

list.item: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . i. Fieri nequit, vt magna ante parua docearis.
Non fuit in primo condita Roma die.
Nulla res consummata est, dum incipit. Sen.
Per partes peruenitur ad totum. Sen. 1. Epist. lib. 19.
Experienti danda venia. Liu. lib. 1. cap. 9.

item.hi: It early pricketh, that will be a thorne.
Early boweth the tree, that will a good Cammocke be.
That doeth blossome in the Spring, that will bring foorth fruit in the Autumne.

list.item: Statim & in puero, virtutis fulget indoles.
Statim apparet quae planta frugifera sit futura.
Generosioris arboris fructus statim, cum fructu est. Fab.

item.hi: In my beginning, God be my speed.

list.item: Absque ope diuina, omnes levis auspicato. Plin.
Auspicem dicti & facti cujusvis habe Deum. Aristid.
A Dei cultu auspicandus rerum agendarum tenor. Liu. li. 38. c. 48.
In omnibus rebus principium & finem constitue Deum.

item.hi: Of euill graine, no good seede.
An euill tree bringeth foorth ill fruit.

list.item: A malis egressa est iniquitas. 1. Sam. 2.4.
A squilla non nascitur rosa. Theog.
Mala arbor, malos producit fructus. Matt. 3.7.

item.hi: Hee that soweth thistles, shall reape thornes.
It is good to preuent an euill in the beginning.
By a little and little the wolfe eateth the sheepe.
It is good to stop the fountaines of the proceedings.
It is the part of a foole to say, I had n •• thought.

list.item: Et neglecta solent incendia sumere vires. Hor.
Opprime dum noua sunt subiti mala semina morbi.
Malagma quaeras iam sub nascenti vlceri.
Cum mala per longas convaluëre moras.
Satius est mederi, initijs quàm fini.
Pharmaca nascenti sunt adhibenda malo. Ouid.
Parua scintilla neglecta magnum excitavit incendium.
Facilius vitium excluditur quàm expellitur. Sen.

list.head: ¶ Beggars.

item.hi: Here a little, and there a little.

list.item: Nec passim, nec omnia, nec ab omnibus.
Minuta commoda non sunt negnegligenda. Zenod.

item.hi: Misery may bee the mother, when one beggar beggeth of another.

list.item: Miler est quisquis faelicitatem sperat à miseris. Sen.

item.hi: Beggars must be no chusers.
Much a doe to bring Beggars to the stockes.
More a doe then needeth.

list.item: Magnus versatur in re parva. Plan.

item.hi: The beggar may sing before the thiefe.
Who can sing so merry a note, as hee that is not worth a groate.
Little goods, little cares.

list.item: Cantabit vacuus coram latrone viator. Virg.
Diuitiae trepidant, paupertas libera res est.
Dives vna cum diuitijs magnam curarum sarcinam accipit.

item.hi: One beggar in woe, when another doeth by the doore goe.

list.item: Aegrè est malis, habere aliquem ipsi quo carent.
Non amat ante larem pauper habere parem.
Invidus & inimicus vicinorum o culos. Hier.
Vna domus non alit duos canes. Aristoph.

item.hi: Benefites binde.
One good turne asketh, or craueth another.

list.head: ¶ Better, or best.

item.hi: Best is best cheape.
One sute of good apparell is worth two of bad.
One good dinner is worth two bad.

list.item: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . i. quod optimum, est honorandum.
Nullus emptor difficilis, bonus emit merces. Pollux.

list.head: ¶ Betters, or Superiors.

item.hi: It is no medling with our betters.
No striuing with the mightie.
It is better to bow, then breake.

list.item: Omne trahit secum Caesaris ira malum. Ouid.
Fumantem vrsi nasum ne tentaveris. Martial.
Si stimulos pugnis caedis, manus plus dolet. Plaut.

list.head: ¶ Beautie.

item.hi: They are pretie, that haue pretie conditions.
A blacke raisin as good as a white.
A faire face must haue good conditions.

list.item: Certus amor morum, formam populabitur aetas.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . i. Non judica pulchritudinem videns, sed mores.
Nihil indignum egregiâ formâ committendum est.
Fastus inest pulchris, sequiturque superbia formam. Ouid.

item.hi: Shee that is faire, hath halfe her portion.

list.item: Formosa facies est muta commendatio. Syr.
Flos virtutis futurae est pulchritudo corporis.

list.head: ¶ Beauty or fairnesse.

item.hi: Beauty is but a blossome.
Beauty is a vaine
thing.
image.
Beauty is no heritage.
The fairest things will fade.

list.item: Florem decoris singuli carpant dies. Sen.
Forma est sepulchrum, purpurae fuco illitum.

list.head: ¶ A Blabbe, or blabbing.

item.hi: He telleth tales out of schoole.
A broken sacke will hold no corne.
Water will run out of a leaking vessel.
He cannot hold, but all must out.
Tell twas, and all the towne must talke of it.

list.item: Non retinent patulae commissa fideliter aures.
Perit omne seruo quod comittis futili.
Plenus est rimarum perfluit, hac & illac. Ter.
Percontatorem fugito, nam garrulus idem est.
Hirundines sub eodem tecto ne habeas.
Stulta est fides celare quod prodas statim. Sen.
In pertusum dolium non ingerenda dicta. Plaut.

list.head: ¶ Blackenesse.

item.hi: The crow is not more black then his feathers.
A blacke grape is as good as the white.
Pepper is blacke, and snow is white.

list.item: Amor formae oblivio rationis. Hi • r.
Alba ligustra cadunt vaccinia nigra leguntur. Virg.
Non deformitate corporis deformatur animus. Sen.

list.head: Blindnesse.

item.hi: He is a blinde buzzard.
He is as blinde as a moull.
He cannot see wood for trees.

list.item: O mentem Cimerijs tenebris atrociorem. Lact.
Res ante pedes pofitas non videt. Cic.

item.hi: The Blinde can iudge of no colour.

list.item: Visu carentem magna pars veri latet. Sen.
Heu maximum malorum omnium caecitas. Basil. Seleuc.

item.hi: If the blinde lead the blinde, they both fall into the ditch.

list.item: Dux saepe cladis causa non exercitus.
Stultissimum est docere alios quod nescias.

item.hi: If it were a Beare it would bite you.

list.item: In manibus habet quod quaerit. Plato.

item.hi: He would make him beleeue that the Moone is made of greene cheese.
Hee hath a great head, and a little wit.
Fooles had neuer lesse wit in a yeere.
He hath no braines.
He hath a leaden head, and woodden wit.

list.head: ¶ Boasting, or bragging.

item.hi: Great boast and small roste maketh vnsauorie mouthes.
Much brann • , and little meale.
Great cry, and little wooll.
Greene thoughts, and great minds.
He that talketh most, fighteth lest.
He maketh a long haruest of a little corne.

list.item: Saepe minùs faciunt homines qui magna minantur.
Qui de se praedicant arrogantiùs, malos habent vicinos.

item.hi: Cannot you be content to farewell, but you must crie rost meat?

list.item: Inuidiam fugies, si in sinu gaudebis, & tua bona non iactabis.
Non sat te tuum fecisse officium, nisi & fama approbat?
Magni viri vt securè viuerent, virtutem, & ingenium ad tempus occultârunt.
Inuidiam nimio cultu vitare memento. Cato.
Si corpus posset tacitus pasci, haberet.

list.head: ¶ Boldnesse, or confidence.

item.hi: He is more bold then wise.
Who is so bolde as blinde bayard?
Foole hardie.
Bolde Beauchampe.
A man may loose his goods for want of demanding them.

list.item: Pudor in rebus suis repetundis inutilis.

list.head: ¶ Bondage, or seruitude.

item.hi: A seruant or apprentise is no master.
They that are bound, must obey.
One must be a seruant before that he can be a master.

list.item: Odi seruum qui hero suo altiùs sapit.

item.hi: Hee is ready to runne at euery mans whistle.

list.item: Frusto panis conduci potest, vt taceat, vel loquatur.

item.hi: Hee hath his head vnder his girdle.
He holdeth his nose to the grindestone.
Many leade their captiues in chaines.

list.item: Pennas ita recidit, vt renasci nequeant. Cic.

list.head: ¶ Borrowing.

item.hi: It is better to buy then borrow.
He that goeth a borrowing, goeth a sorrowing.

list.item: Nulla res chariùs constat quàm quae precibus emitur. Senec.
Nisi quis se domesticis instruxerit copijs, aliunde petere non potest. Cic.

item.hi: If euery bird had his owne, he should be as rich as a new shorne sheepe.

list.item: Moueat cornicula risum, furtiuis nudata coloribus. Hor.

item.hi: They chide hand-smoothe.

list.head: ¶ Bribery.

item.hi: To grease a man in the fist.
To cast dust into a mans eyes.
There is no earthly gate, which an asse laden with golde cannot enter into.
A bribe entreth euery where without knocking.
Money will doe any thing in these dayes.
A man must fish with the siluer hook.

list.item: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . i. auaritia Spartum capiet, aliud verò nihil.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . i. Aureis pugnabis hastis, & cuncta expugnabis.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . i. dona persuadent D • js & reuerendis Regibus.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . i. virtutem & sapientiam vincunt testudines, (i. nummi.)
Aureis & argenteis gradibus ad honores ascenditur.
Nulla arx prorsus expugnabilis, in quam onustus asellus auro intromitti non potest. Cic.

item.hi: Gifts enter without knocking.

list.item: Dantes admittit, non dantibus ostia claudit.
Nil clausum constat quod auro argentoque non patet. Val. Epist. in serm.

list.head: ¶ Burden.

item.hi: Light burden for heauie.
The longer that seruice is, the bitterer.

list.item: Magnitudinem calamitatis ipsum tempus aggrauat. Diod. Sic.
Longâ malorum sensus accrescit die. Sen.
Mors minùs paenae quàm mora mortis habet.

list.head: ¶ Busie, or medling.

item.hi: Busie will haue bondes.
Euery foole wilbe medling.
He is more busie, then he hath thankes for his labour.
A medlar is as he that taketh a wolfe by the eares.
Hee that will meddle with all things, may goe shoe the goose.
He hath an oare in euery mans boat.

list.item: Dominos habere debet qui se non hab • t. Mart.
Quibus ipsis nulla est res quam curent sua.
Linguam cum manibus nescit compescere stultus.
Viro Lydo negotium non erat, at ipse foris profectus parauit. Zenod.
In alieno choro pedem ponit. Plut.
Aliena curat, & quae ad se nihil pertinent. Terent.
Mala attrahit ad se, vt magnes lapis. Gellius.

item.hi: Who is more busie then hee that hath least to doe?

list.item: Alienas res qui curant studio maximo, quibus ipsis nulla est res quàm procurent sua. Plaut.

item.hi: He hath many irons in the fire.

list.item: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Zenophon. lib. 8. Cyrop.
Omnibus intentus minor est ad singula sensus.
Eius rei non sunt plures actus essentiales. Aristot.

item.hi: He hath both his hands full.
Hee hath as much as hee can turne him to.

list.item: Vix vnus plures artes exercet cum laude Hydram secat.

item.hi: Neither idle nor well occupied.

list.item: A man full of spirit cannot be idle.
Nihil agendo, homines discunt male agere.
Illi alienas res studio curant maximo, quibus nulla est res quam procurent sua.
Quicunque non facit bonum, malum facit.
Qui nihil videntur agere, maiora agunt.
Ferè nouant res quibus nulla res est domi.

item.hi: Cheape sold and deare bought.

list.item: Quod non opus est, asse carum est.

item.hi: He buieth and selleth and liueth by the losse.
An ill market-man.

list.item: Nihil venditori debet qui carè emit.
Res non potest consistere vbi quaestum superat sumptus.

item.hi: He that cannot aske, cannot liue.
A man must aske excessiuely to get a little.

list.item: Iniquum petendum vt aequum feras. Quint.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . i. summum cape, & medium habebis. Zenod.

item.hi: A man must buie at the faire, and sell at home.

list.item: Omnes voluit viliter emere & carè vendere. Aug. de ciuit. Dei.
Aequum est homini ad suum esse quaestum, callidum. Plaut.

item.hi: A foole demandeth much but the more foole is he that giueth it.

list.item: Mala emptio semper ingrata est, eo maxime quòd exprobare stultitiam Domino videtur.

list.head: ¶ Care, or thought.

item.hi: CAre bringeth gray haires.
Care groweth through his hood.
Care will kill a Cat.
Care will kill an horse.

list.item: Cura facit canos, quamuis quis non habet annos.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . i. Mens solicita est tinea paredens ossa.
Curae, magis secretae, magis animum lancinant. Sen.
Etiam viros debellat inuictos dolor. Ouid.

list.head: ¶ Cattes.

item.hi: A Cat may looke on a king.
The view of merchandice will cost a man nothing.
A man may keepe the Kings high way.
One may think who dareth not speak.

list.item: Nil offendunt oculi, si oculis animus imperet.
Aestimari nos putemus toties, quoties aspici. Senec. de Ttranq. am. c. 15.
Aequabilitas in omni vita est optima. Cic.
Diem, aquam, noctem, solem, lunam, haec argento non emo. Plautus.
Iura omnibus sunt vrbis aequa liberae.
Aliquid commune est generis humani. Sen.

item.hi: It is not for nought that the Cat winketh when both her eyes are out.
The Cat knoweth whose lippes shee licketh.
The dogg • waggeth his taile, not for you, but for your bread.

list.item: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . i. Malus videtur sui causâ omnia facere.

list.head: ¶ Cauelling.

item.hi:
Cauill will enter in at any hole, and if it find 〈…〉
• ill make one.
Ill will neuer spake well.

list.item: Homo peruersus quicquid rectè dicitur, in diuersam partem rapit.
Aduersus inuidiam nihil prodest vera dicere.

item.hi: One may easily finde a staffe to beat a dog withall.

list.item: Facilè invenias baculum quo caedas canem.
Malefacere qui vult, nunquam non inuenit causam.
Irasci tantum faelices nostis amici. Mari.
Non quia sic merui, sed iuuat hoc facere.

list.head: ¶ Certaintie.

item.hi: It is better to enioy, then hope.
One bird in the hand, is better then two in the bush.
He that leaueth certaintie, and leaueth vnto chance, when fooles pipe, by authoritie he may dance.

list.item: Stultus est qui praesentia relinquens, absentia persequitur.

Occulatae sunt manus nostrae. Plaut.
Credunt quod vident.
Melior & tutior est certa pax, quàm incerta victoria. Cic.

list.head: ¶ Change, or alteration.

item.hi: There is change of all things.
Nothing continueth long in one estate.

list.item: Non semper idem floribus est honos Vernis, neque vno luna rubens colore nitet.
Nihil diu in eodem statu manet.

Vt res dant sese, ita magni, & humiles
sumus. Terent.
Mortalium vita est vnus tantum dies. Quint. Declam. 4.
Ipsa dies quando{que} parens quandoque nouerca. Hesiod.
Cum Deo quisque, & gaudet & flet. Sophoc.

list.head: ¶ Change, or exchange.

item.hi: He stealeth a goose, and sticketh down a feather.
Change is no roberie.

list.item: Pilos pro lana quis detondeat? Theocr.

item.hi: After a calme commeth a storme.

list.item: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . i. In vitae tranquillitate, expecta rerum tempestatem.

item.hi: New meats prouoke the appetite.

list.item: Similitudo mater satietatis in omnibus. Cic. lib. de Inuent. c. 42.
Palatum non nisi ad pretiosos cibos excitatur. Sen. lib. consid. ad Albinum.

list.head: ¶ Charitie, or loue.

item.hi: Let charitie measure all your actions.

list.item: Quicquid dubium est, humanitate inclinat in melius. Sen. Epist. 5. lib. 11.
Noli accusare proximum, sed potius excusa, excusa intentionem, si opus non potes. Bern.

list.head: ¶ Children.

item.hi: Children are the parents riches.

list.item: Satis magnum regnum est marito, liberi & vxor.
Beatus est, qui est beatus in liberis.
Virorum sunt corona liberi, patris est filius.

item.hi: It is better that children weepe, then old men.
Spare the rod, and spill the child.
He that loueth his children, correcteth them well.

list.item: Melius est vt adolescens rubeat, quàm palleat.
Res vtilis esse adolescentiam in metu. Terent.

item.hi: The yong cocke croweth as he heareth the olde:
The sonne reteineth the fathers spirits.
Like father, like sonne: like mother, like daughter.

list.item: Qualis pater, talis filius: qualis mater, talis filia.
Filius vt similis patri, sic filia matri.

item.hi: Children often tell trueth.
Little pitchers haue eares.

list.item: Si secretarum seriem, vis noscere rerum.
Ebrius, insipiens, pueri dicent tibi verum.
Pueria critur animaduertunt, quae non existimes. Cic.
Nihil est puero teste certius. lib. 4. Controu.
Pueri celant nihil. Sen. in Thyest.

item.hi: It is a deare collop, that is taken out of the flesh.
The ape so long straineth, (or clippeth) her yong ones, vntill she kill them.
The Crow thinketh her owne birdes fairest.

list.item: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . i. natura diligit prolem.
Amare nimium, est odio habere liberos.
Blanda patrum segnes facit indulgentia natos. Iuve.

list.head: ¶ Choice, or varietie.

item.hi: New meate bringeth a new appetite.

list.item: Nihil est molestius quàm quod semper est idem.
Crambe bis posita, mors est. Suid.
Famam incitat non sedat caena splendida.

list.head: ¶ Comfort.

item.hi: After raine, faire weather.
After a storme commeth a calme.
When bale is highest, boote is next.

list.item: Nube solet pulsâ, candidus ire dies. Ouid.
Non si nunc male, sic, & olim. Hor.
Dei auxilium est in aduersis praefentissimum. Psal 46.11.
Notus non semper paturit imbres perpetuos. Horat.
O passi graviora, Deus dabit his quo{que} finem. Virg.
Aeternitas constat rerum contrarijs. Sen. Epist.. 107.

list.head: ¶ Commoditie, or profite.

item.hi: Euery Commoditie hath his discommoditie.

list.item: Omnia commoditas sua fert incommoda secum. Hor.
Nullum commodum sine adiuncto incommodo. Ter.
Bona hora nemini, est, vt non sit alicui mala.
Bonum sine malo in hac vita esse nequit.

item.hi: Want of mony, want of comfort.
When we want mony, we want all.

list.item: Si Fortuna perit, nullus amicus erit.
Pecuniae sunt necessariae, sine quibus nihil rectè geripotest. Demost. 3. Olynth.

item.hi: A full purse will make the mouth to speake.
A Lawyer will not pleade but for money.
All for what will ye giue me.

list.item: Dej immortales obsecro aurum quid valet?
Vt luti baiuli, nihil nisi dato nummo facit. Aristoph.

item.hi: Hee knoweth on what side his bread is buttered.

list.item: Novit ex qua parte lucrum acrescit sibi.
Est ad suum quaestum quisque callidus. Plaut.

item.hi: Hee is not wise, that is not wise for himselfe.
Hee is wise, that can keepe himselfe warme.
Euery Miller draweth water to his owne mill.

list.item: Omnes sibi melius esse malunt, quàm alteri. Terent.
Habenda ratio rei familiaris quam dilabi sinere flagitiosum est. Cic.

list.head: ¶ Common.

item.hi: The Kings high way is common to all.

list.item: Nemo quenquam ire prohibet publicâ viâ. Sen.
Diem, aquam, solem, lunam, noctem, haec argento non emes.

list.head: ¶ Companie.

item.hi: As a man is, so is his companie.
Like to like.
Tell mee with whom thou goest, and I will tell thee what thou doest.

list.item: Ex socijs, poculis, ioculis, vir qualis sit cognoscitur. Ex Rabbinis.
Qualis quisque sit, ex socijs cognoscitur.
Talis quis{que} est, cum qualibus versatur.
Pares cum paribus facillimè congregantur. Cic.
Plerumque tales sumus, quales ij, quibuscum vivimus.

item.hi: Companie maketh a man spend.

list.item: Perfacile est rem benè paratam comitate perdere. Plau.

item.hi: A man for all companies.
Ill company bringeth a man to the galowse.

list.item: Si iuxta claudum habites, subclaudicare disces. Plut.

item.hi: It is better to bee alone, then in ill companie.
One scabbed sheepe, marreth all the folde.

list.item: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . i. noxia est conuersatio cum malis.
Corrumpunt mores bonos colloquia prava. Menand.
Vnica prava pecus totum corrumpit ovile.
Consuetudo cum malis, est nequitiae pabulum.
Torpedini similis marino torpidos reddit qui tangunt.

list.head: ¶ Conceitednesse.

item.hi: There is not an asse amongst them, but hee is worthy to stand amongst the Kings horses, in the same stable.

list.item: Illi soli sapiunt volitant alij velut vmbra. Hom.

item.hi: He thinketh his halfepenie good siluer.
All his geese are swannes.
The ignorant is conceited that hee flyeth.
He thinketh that the ground carrieth him not.
A Cuckow thinketh her selfe a fine birde.

list.item: Hoc tantùm rectum quod facit, ipse putat.
Sua plus iusto carmina quisque probat.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . i. multi autumant se aliquid esse cum nihil sint.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . i. qui vana opinione plenus est, ille est vter.
Nemo non oculis apertis sua computat bona. Petron.

item.hi: He can easily see or espie a mote in an other mans eye, but he cannot discerne a beame in his owne.
Hee is Eagle eyed in other mens matters, but as blind as a buzzard in his owne.

list.item: Cùm tua peruideas oculis mala lippus inunctis. Hor.
Cur in amicorum vitijs tam cernis acutè?
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Bas. i. Est faciliùs aliena tractare quam propria considerare.
Non videt id Manticae quod in tergo est. Plaut.
Qui me deridet, non sua facta videt.
Stultitiae est aliena vitia cernere oblivisci suorum.
Spectat festucam quae est in oculo fratris sui, trabem verò quae est in oculo suo, non animaduertit. Matth. 7.3.
In suo quisque negotio hebetior quam in alieno.
In alienis rebus Linceus, in suis talpa.

list.head: ¶ Confession.

item.hi: Hee that will bee healed of his sinnes, must confesse them.
The confession of a fault, is halfe an amends.

list.item: Initium salutis est notitia peccati. Sen. Epist. 9. lib. 3.
Vitia confiteri est, initium sanctitatis. Sen.
Crimina ne celes magna est medicina fateri. Cato.
Maior culpa quo citiùs agnoscitur, eo celeriùs emendatur.
Veniâ dignus est qui de peccato excusationem non quaerit. Val.

item.hi: Confesse and be hanged.

list.item: Vbi turpis est medicina fateri pudet. Ouid.
Quis furor est quae nocte latent, peccata fateri? Ouid.
Nemo iniurium fatetur se cum est maximè.
Nemo vult fateri vitia alijs sua.

item.hi: Hide nothing from thy Pastour, Physician, Lawyer.
There is no curing of a griefe concealed.

list.item: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . i. Alimentum morborum est silentium, sed quod enuntiatur, facilè potest sanari.
Curae secretae magis mentem lancinant. Senec.
Crescit dissimulatione ipse dolor, hoc altiùs demissus quo minùs profiteri licet. Iust. lib. 8. c. 9.

list.head: ¶ Conscience.

item.hi: The conscience is a thousand witnesses.
Euery man is best knowen to himselfe.

list.item:
Plus ponderis est in testimonio
tuo, quam in alieno conuitio. Bern.
Purus ille est qui est nullius sibi mali consciùs.

item.hi: Euery tubbe must stand on his owne bottome.
Euery man must see by his owne eyes.

list.item: Meliùs videas oculis proprijs quàm alienis.
Quicquid non est ex fide, est peccatum, Rom. 14.

item.hi: He that do •• h euill, hateth the light.
The light is naught for sore eyes.
Greene wounds will not be touched.
Agalled horse no combe abideth.
A thiefe hideth himselfe in a bush.

list.item: Nihil est miseriùs quam animus malè sibi conscius.
Post scelera summa, non invenit somnus locum.
In nocturna sacra quaevis competit suspicio.
Nihil timidum facit nisi reprehensibilis vitae conscientia. Sen.
Quae dolent ea molestum est contingere.
Laesus & conturbatus oculus non fert lumen.

item.hi: Raw leather will stretch.
Men will straine hard for profit.

list.item: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . i. vbi est lucrum ibi contra naturam seruiendum est.
Argentum & aurum sunt omnis sceleris materies.
Diues omnis aut iniquus est, aut iniqui haeres.
Ad malas artes animum adducit quaestus.
Auri sacra fames, quid non mortalia cogit pectora? Virg.
Ibi fas vbi maxima merces. Cla • d.

item.hi: Where no fault is, there needeth no pardon.
A good conscience is a continuall feast.
Innocency bringeth a defense with it.

list.item: Conscia mens recti famae mendacia spernit.
Veritatis amator nullum sanc castigatorem timet.
Optimum est in vita praeter scipsum nihil temere.
Nil conscire sibi nullâ pallescere culpâ.

item.hi: Conscience is hanged vp long agoe.

list.item: Rupere faedus impius lucri fu ror, & ira praeceps. In Hippol.

item.hi: Science is naught worth without conscience.

list.item: Longè caeteris peritior est, non multo melior tamen.
Scientia absque aequo fraus est, non scientia. Cic.
Multae literae magis doctum faciunt (hominem) quàm probum. Sen.
Nihil tam acerbus est in quo aequus animus solatium non inueniat. Sen. de tranquil. animi.
Gaudium non nascitur nisi ex virtutis conscientia. Sen.
Beatus est cui gaudium omne ex se nascitur. Sen.
Vera laetitia intra teipsum nascitur. Sen.

item.hi: To him that hath lost his taste, sweet is sowre.

list.item: Non omnia omnibus sunt aequè suauia.
Caeno puram aquam turbans nunquam inuenies potum.

list.head: Contempt.

item.hi: Heere is the doore, and there is the way.
He is no body.
He is a cipher amongst numbers.

list.item: Neque arte nec Marte, neque cerâ, nec aere, nobilis.

item.hi: He scorneth the motion.

list.item: Cum inferiore contendere est sordidum. Sen

item.hi: S. George on Horsebacke.
He standeth for a cipher.
He ouerlooketh him, as the Diuell looked ouer Lincolne.
Let him that is cold blow at the coale.
Let him put his finger in the fire that needeth.

list.item: Mea res non est, longè valeat.
Ecquis periculo rem alienam curat suo.

item.hi: He may goe shake his eares.
He careth no more for him then his old shoes.
Hee is Iohn herbe in the pottage, that will doe neither good nor harme.

list.item: Neque bonum neque malum faciet. Ezech. 9.

item.hi: Let him make a page of his age.
I owe him not so much seruice.

list.item: Qui honorat à quibus ipse contemnitur, similis est asino. Ex Rabbinis.
Acquum est venire ad cum, a quo ipse quid velis. Caes. lib. 1. Gal. c. 34

item.hi: A fig for him.
Let him doe his worst.

list.item: Semper me tales hostes insequantur. Suid.
Securus rideo, non moror illius minas.

item.hi: He is good for nothing.
Hom.

list.head: ¶ Contention.

item.hi: They agree together like cats and dogs.
They are at daggers drawing.
They are at deadly fewd.
They agree like harpe and harrow.

list.item: Concordes vnus capit lectulus, sed discordes ne tota quidem domus. Plaut.

item.hi: Two dogs striue for a bone, and the third whiles that they contend, taketh it away.
Hatred with friends is succour to foes.
I know that if I contend with durtie foes, I must be foyled whether I win or lose.
I will not staine my hands with him.

list.item: Hoc scio pro certo, quanto plus stercore certo.
Vinco, seu vincor, semper ego maculor.

item.hi: He hath cast a bone betweene them.
Hee hath set them together by the cares.

list.item: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . i. contentionis pomum in medium proiecit. Niceph. Calist. lib. 14.

list.head: ¶ Contentment.

item.hi: He hath nothing that is not content.

list.item: Felix non qui habet, sed qui non cupit quae habet.
Avaro tam deest quod habet, quam quod non habet.

item.hi: Contentment is great riches.
Nothing is better then a contented mind.
Enough is as good as a feast.
Fie vpon riches that haue no contentment.

list.item: Is maxime opibus fruitur qui minime indiget. Sen.
Eget minus mortalis, quo minus cupit.
Satis divitiarum nihil amplius velle. Quin.
Quid magnum ei esse potest, cui mundus est nihil? Cic.
Vtrum non desideres quid, an habeas, nihil interest. Sen.
Virtus nihil cupit quod abest, gaudet praesentibus.
Summa quies nil velle supra quàm postulat vsus.
Benè est cui Deus obtulit. Boetius.
Parcâ, quod satis est manu. Boet.
Qui est suis contentus, est ditissimus.
Laetus in praesens, animus quod vltra est oderit. Hor.
In secundus nemo confidat, in aduersis nemo desperat. Sen. lib. 3. de natural. quaest.

item.hi: A man must keepe himselfe well when he is well.
It is better to sit still, then to rise and fall.

list.item: Non expedit concutere faelicem statum. Sen.
Faelices sunt, qui sua nôrunt bona. Agr.

Non minor est virtus quám quaerere
parta tueri.
Non habere diuitias est leuior dolor quam perdere.
Nil citô mutabis, donec meliora videbis.
Si quâ sede sedes, & congrua sit tibi sedes.
Istâ sede sede, nec ab istâ sede recede.
Maritimus cum sis, ne fieri velis terrestris.

item.hi: He that doeth well, wearieth not himselfe.
Neuer wearie of that which is good.

list.item: Tamdiu discendum quamdiu viuas. Sen. Epist. 7. lib. 10.
Si propiùs stes, te capiet magis, ac decies repetita placebit. Horat.

item.hi: A man must doe as he can, when hee cannot as he would.
A man must take all well in worth, that God hath sent.

list.item: Viuas vt possis, quando non quis vt velis. Terent.
Bona est offa post panem. Zenod.
Praesentem capram mulge quid fugientem persequeris? Theocr.

list.head: ¶ Correction.

item.hi: Hee that chastiseth one, amendeth many.

list.item: Poena non tam ad delictum pertinet quam ad exemplum. Quintil. Decl. 274.
Vnius improbi supplicio, multorum improbitas est coercenda. 3. actio in Verrem. Cic.

item.hi: He hath cut his combe.
He hath taken him an hole lower.
Doe the like againe.
His mouth runneth ouer.
Backe an ace quoth Bourne.
Bate me an ace quoth Boulton.

list.head: ¶ Couetousnesse.

item.hi: All haue, all foregoe.
All couet all loose.
Who too much gripeth, the lesse holdeth.
That he getteth in the hundred, he looseth in the shire.

list.item: Et hamum & escam saepe piscis abstulit.
Rapiendi auiditas insidiatur militi. Marcellinus lib. 23. c. 15.
Plurima si quaeras, multam patiere repulsam.
Auidus secundis, non est cautus tristibus.
Camelus desiderans cornua aures perdidit. Aesop.
Praeceps ad ditescendum non fit impune. Prou.

item.hi: Eger of the world.
Greedy of the world.
Gripple of the world.
He is neuer content.
He hath the siluer dropsie.
Much would haue more.
He seeth no green cheese, but his mouth doth water after it.
He would all haue, and naught forgo.

list.item: Improbae crescunt diuitiae, tamen curtae nescio quid semper abest rei. Hor.
Quo plus sunt potae, plus sitiuntur aquae.
Quis metus aut pudor est vnquam properantis auari?
Nemo est cui fortuna sua satisfacit. Sen.
Improbus beneficium sumere scit, sed nescit reddere.

item.hi: All is fish with him that commeth to the net.
Raw leather will stretch.
He would haue the Diuell and all.

list.item: Boni lucri odor ex re qualibet. Iuuen.
Nihil ei turpe, cui pretium placet. Sen.
A rebus sacris non abstinet manus.

item.hi: All for what will you giue me.
He must be greased in the fist.

list.item: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Bion. i. Mater malitiae est auaritia.

list.head: ¶ Counsell.

item.hi: Good counsell will doe no harme.
It is good to be well aduised.
He can giue others good counsell, but will take none himselfe.

list.item: Faciliùs quis consulit alijs quam sibi.
Facilè, cum valemus, aegrotis concilia damus. Terent.
Frustrà sapit qui sibi non sapit. Eurip.
Qui sibi non sapiunt alteri monstrant viam.

item.hi: Two heads are better then one.
A man must build on a good foundation.
Good counsell will sometimes doe more then a thousand men.

list.item: Finis est primus in intentione & vltimus executione.
Cunctari solet qui tentat rem magnam.
Vbi consilium verum est, ibi est imperium prosperum. Salust. epist. altera ad Caium.
Ducis in consilio posita est virtus militum.
Ei auscultandum, cui quatuor sunt aures.
Quis sapiens qui discit e quouis homine?
Nullius sensum si prodest, tempseris vnquam. Cato.
Saepe etiam stultus fuit opportuna loquutus.

list.head: ¶ Countrey or natiue soile.

item.hi: Euery stranger loueth his Countrey.

list.item: Nescio qua natale solum dulcedine cunctos
Ducit, & immemores non sinit esse sui. Ouid.
Est aliquid patriae vicinus finibus esse.
Sal patriae pluris faciendus est quam hospitis mensa. Aesch.

list.head: ¶ The Court.

item.hi: A man must come to the Court as Iob, and abide there as Vlysses.

list.item: Quot diverticula Curialium tot Cerberi sunt. Ioh. Sarisb. polyc. c. x.
In aula multae iniuriae sunt dissimulandae.

item.hi: A man must heare & see in the Court, and for the rest be blind.

list.item: Audire plus quam fari aulicum decet.
Si quis in aula gratiam consequeretur, (id fit) iniurias accipiendo & gratias agendo.

list.head: ¶ Cowardise, dastardlinesse.

item.hi: Bragge is a good dogge.
A cocke on his owne dunghill.
He that talketh most, fighteth little.

list.item: In Castris feroces, in acie pauidi. Liu.
Fisus loco, vel maximas vincat copias.
Gallus in suo sterquilinio plurimum potest.
Quid Achivos à terra indicatis? Aristo.
Quem mater dedit, solicitè tuetur amictum. Quint.
Canis ignavus lapidem mordet, eo qui misit omisso. Plato.
Solus qui currit facilè vincit Luc.
Quum adsit via semitam quaerit. Eustath.

item.hi: He will saue one.

list.item: Quem mater amictum dedit solicitè custodit. Quint. Plut.
Testudo intra tegumen suum tuta est. Liv.

item.hi: A coward often changeth colour.
A foole putteth his finger in an hole.
His heart is in his heeles.

list.item: Galeam recusat caput opertum linteo. Hier.

Cervinus vir.
His taile doeth make buttons.

Similis est captivis ex pylo.
A souldier in a paire of sheets.

item.hi: He sheweth a faire paire of heeles.
One paire of heeles, is worth two paire of hands.

list.item: Faedissima armis quae fit abiectis, fuga. Salust.
Cum licet fugere, ne quaere litem.

Nil poterit iust â tutiùs esse fugâ.
— Timor addidit alas,
Currit vt auditis territa dama lupis.

list.head: ¶ Craft.

item.hi: Craft bringeth nothing home.
He that deceiueth another, is oft deceiued himselfe.
The subtilest are oft ouertaken.

list.item: Malo herclè vestro, tam versutè viuitis. Plaut.
Dolosus non assabit quod venando cepit. Prox.
Multi se stolidè frustrantur, cum alios frustrari aestimant. Plaut.
Quidam versantur in dolis, & ijs res quaelibet aduersatur.

list.head: ¶ Craft.

item.hi: To deceiue a deceiuer is no deceit.

list.item: Iudice me, fraus est concessa repeliere fraudem;
Arma{que} in armatos sumere jura sinunt. Ouid.

item.hi: One beateth the bush, and another catcheth the bird.

list.item: Alij sementem faciunt, alij metunt. Hesiod.
Ego apros occido, sed alter fruitur pulpamento. Diocles.

list.head: ¶ Crosse.

item.hi: The Crosse is the ladder of heauen.

list.item: Omnis, Christiani vita crux & Martyrium. Mar. in ser. de Martyrio.

list.head: ¶ Crueltie.

item.hi: Cruell people are fearefull.

list.item: Necesse est multos timeat, quem multi timent. Senec.
Qui sceptra duro saevus imperio premit;
Timet timentes, metus in auctorem redit.
Quicquid terret, trepidat. Sen. lib. 2. de ira.
Domi leones, foris & in bello vulpeculae. Aristoph.
Tumidus secundis, timidus est idem in malis Tac. lib. 3.
Comes tyranno, vt vmbra corpori, it timor.
Vnicum tyrannidis tutamen est diffidentia. Diod. lib. 20. c. 64.

list.head: ¶ Cunning, or learning.

item.hi: Cunning is no burden.
A man cannot be robbed of his learning.

list.item: Invia virtuti nulla est via. Sen.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . i. Literae sunt pulcherrimae hominum divitiae.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . i. duplum vident qui didicerunt literas.
Doctus sua bona secum portat. Cic.
Subiecta nulli mentis & animi bona. Sen.

list.head: ¶ Curiositie.

item.hi: Hee is more precise (or busie) then wise.
Hee is more curious then is needfull.

list.item: Curiosus nemo est, qui non sit maleuolus. Plaut.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . i. Multae amentiae est, venari mania.
Quod indicari non bonum est, malè quaeritur.

list.head: ¶ Custome, or vsage.

item.hi: Custome is another nature.
In vaine they rise early, who vsed to rise late.

list.item: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . i. Consuetudo est altera natura.
Consuetudo vim naturae obtinet propter vetustatem. Cic.
Dediscit animus serò, quae didicit diu.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . i. Difficile est consuetudinem longam corrigere. Philo.
Quod consuetum est, velut innatum est.
Quod difficile est, consuetudo facile • fficit.
Maxima vis est vetustatis & consuetudinis. Cic.
Consuetudini si non resistitur, fit habitus.
Difficulter reciduntur vitia, quae nobiscum creverunt. Sen.
Difficilius est dediscere quàm discere. Arist. lib. 4. polit. c. 1.

item.hi: Tables and dice are better giuen ouer then vsed.
A good custome must roote cut that, which an ill hath brought in, or vp.

list.item: Aleator, quanto est in arte peritior, tanto est nequior. Syr.
Bona consuetudo debet excu • ere, quod mala introduxit.

list.head: ¶ Danger, or perill.

item.hi: HEe is in a pecke of troubles.
Betweene the anuill and the hammer.
Hee is in the suds.
He is in a brake.

list.item: Nihil ei beatum, cui semper aliquis terror impender.
A fronte praecipitia, à tergo lupi.

item.hi: He pulleth an old house on his head.
He putteth his hand betwixt the hatchet, and the wood.

list.item: In suum ipsius malum deducit lunam.

item.hi: The coast is not cleare.
All is not well.
Somewhat is in brewing.
There is a pad in the straw.

list.item: Saepe tacens odij semina, vultus habet.
Grauius omne malum quod sub aspectu latet. Syr.
Cauendum semper, multae insidi • e bonis.
Semper plus metuit animus ignorans malum.

item.hi: Let this winde be ouerblowen.
The iourney is safe when the enemies are gone.

list.item: Priùs apes abigendae, deinde mel subtrahendum.
In bello magis tergo quàm fronti prospice.

item.hi: He hath escaped a scouring.

list.item: Habet praeteriti doloris secura recordatio delectationem.
Nunc benè navigavit, quum naufragium fecerit. Reg.

item.hi: When the danger is past, men reioyce.

list.item: Non iactet qui accingit se, ac qui discingit. 1. Reg. 20.11.
Quae fuit durum pati, meminisse dulce est. Cic.

list.head: ¶ Deafenesse.

item.hi: As deafe as a doore naile.
Borne in a mill.
As good to speake to a poste.
Hee singeth at a deafe mans doore.
Who is so deafe as hee that will not heare?

list.item: Frustra eos appellamus, quorum aures & animi à nobis abhorrent.
Asino quidam narrabat fabulam, & ille auriculas movebat.

list.head: ¶ Death.

item.hi: All men are mortall.
All must die.
Bee the day neuer so long, at last commeth Euensong.
As soone commeth a lambe to the market, as a sheepe.

list.item: Ducuntur ex plebeia domo funera, ducuntur ex regia. Sen.
Seriùs aut citiùs metam properamus ad vnam.
Senibus mors est in januis, iuvenibus in insidijs. Sen.
Mori necesse est quic quid vsquam nascitur.
Mortem medicus non tollit, mortem protrahit.
Corpus breue hospitium quod mox relinquendum est. Sen.

list.head: ¶ He that looketh for dead mens shoes, may long goe barefoot.
list.item: Aurora cui non est cordi, est cordi vespera.
Alterius expectare opes miserimum est. Cic.
Muscae sequuntur mel, lupi cadavera. Sen.

item.hi: When the serpent is dead, the poyson will not hurt.
A dead man can doe no hurt.
He that pardoneth his enemie, shall die in his hands.

list.item: Extinguere hostem ducis est maxima virtus. Sen.
Ne catulus quidem seruendus ex genere pessimo.
Foelicius occidiffe quem timeas palam. Quint.
Capitales Reipub. pestes, sunt è medio tollendae.
Non poterit cuiquam hostis, esse mortuus.

item.hi: A lightning before death.

list.item: Cantator cygnus funeris ipse sui. Mart.

item.hi: An honourable death followeth an honourable life.
He dieth well, that liueth well.
A good life will haue a good end.

list.item: Dum non ob malefacta pereo, parvi aestimo. Plaut.
Mortis dies, non tam fatalis quàm natalis. Senec.
Mori malè non potest, qui non malè vixerit. Ambr.
Natalis est aeterni, postremus dies. Seneca.
Nunquam vidi malè morientem, qui libenter opera charitatis exercuit. Ambr.

item.hi: It is folly to trust to dead mens bones.
Hee that trusteth to dead mens shoes, may long goe barefoot.

list.item: Expecta anus dum suaviaris filium meum.
Saepe spes futuri incerta, homines certos decipit.
Quis non patri supremum diem optat suum?

item.hi: Euery man must haue something to bring him to his end.

list.item: Telum est abundè, quicquid in mortem trahit. Sen.

item.hi: Hee is in euery mans debt and danger.
Hee dareth not shew his head for debt.

list.head: ¶ Deceit.

item.hi: He gulleth him.
He putteth his nose out of ioynt.
He playeth wily beguile you with himselfe.

list.item: Multi stolidè se frustrantur, cum alios frustrari aestimant. Plaut.
Proclivius nihil est, quàm seipsum fallere. Basil.

item.hi: To deceiue a deceiuer is no deceit.

list.head: ¶ Deeds.

item.hi: Few words and many deeds.
Deeds are fruit, and words are but leaues.
Doe well and haue well.

list.item: Fortunae suae quisque faber. Corn. Nepos.
Sat fautorum semper habet qui rectè facit. Sen.

item.hi: A good deed is neuer lost.

list.item: Rectè factum nulla vis reddit irritum. Sen.
Quod bene fit bonis, haud perit.
Beneficia accipere seputant, cum dant, boni. Symm.

item.hi: Few words, and many deeds.
Doing is better then saying.
The taste of the Kitchen is better then the smell.

list.item: Nequaquam illud verbum, Bene vult, nisi quis benefacit Plaut.
Non opus est verbis, credite rebus, ait.
Quid verbis opus est, spectemur agendo. Ouid.
Iaculis vbi opus est, nil verba conferunt.
Si paria dictis ageret, quid illo foret beatius. Sen.
Suadet loquentis vita, non verò oratio.
Omnis virtus in actione consistit. Cic.

item.hi: A tree is knowen by his fruits, and not by his leaues and flowres.

list.item: Quid verba audiam, cum facta videam?
Spectanda fama hominis, facta at magis. Sen.

list.head: ¶ Degenerate.

item.hi: The nettle groweth where the rose was expected.
The rose prooueth a thorne.

list.item: Quantum mutatus ab illo est. Virg.

item.hi: The stocke is good, but the plants are deg • nerate.
Out of the egge a chicken was expected, but behold a cocatrice.

list.item: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . i. pauci filij sunt parentum similes.
Gloriam a parentibus relictam retinere non est omnium.

list.head: ¶ Delay.

item.hi: Desires are nourished by delay.

list.item: Vbi sitis fauces tenet fodere puteum est miserum. Plaut.
Omnis mora quantumuis pusilla longissima videtur.

item.hi: Short shooting loseth the game.
Delay is dangerous.
Deferre not vntill to morrow, if thou canst do it to day.
Whiles that the grasse groweth, the steed sterueth.

list.item: Rei nulli prodest mora, nisi iracundiae.
Anus expecta dum suauiaris filium meum.
Aequiore animo quidam ferunt praecedi spem suam quam tolli.

item.hi: He looseth his thankes that promiseth and delaieth.
Long hope is the fainting of the soule.

list.item: Spes quae differtur, molesta est. Prou. 13.12.
Longa est rei speratae omnis dilatio.
Nihil aequè amarum spe quam pendere diu.
Quid tu non intelligis, tantum te gratiae demere, quantum morae adijcis? Plaut.

item.hi: A day after the faire.
When the steed is stolen shut the stable doore.

list.item: Cum mala per longas conualuere moras. Ouid.
Lentum mali remedium praecipitis est mora. Sen. lib. 4. de ira.

item.hi: He that staieth in the valley, shall neuer get ouer the hill.

list.item: Vigilandum est omnibus qui cupiunt vincere.
Nihil est incipere, nisi gnauiter perficias.
Vna cum Minerua manus est admouenda.

list.head: ¶ Delight.

item.hi: Euery man hath his delight.
Euery man in his humour.

list.item: Non omnia omnibus sunt aequè suauia. Plaut.
Velle cuique suum est, nec voto viuitur vno. Pers.
Suo quisque studio maximè ducitur. Cic.
Te tua, me mea delectant. Cic.
Non omnes arbustae iuuant humilesque myricae. Virg.
Sues libentius in caeno quam in aquâ purâ versantur.

list.head: A Deniall.

item.hi: Shamefull crauing must haue shamefull denying.

list.item: Iniusta a iustis impetrare non decet.
Musca licet repulsa saepius, insultat morsura tamen.

item.hi: Desperate, or without hope or grace.
He that hath done so much hurt that he can doe no more, must sit downe and rest him.
Some doe mend, when they cannot appaire.
Blacke will take no other colour.
He may doe much ill, eare hee can doe worse.
He hath one fault, he is starke naught.

list.item: Et pudor & probitas & metus omnis abest.
Neque leges, neque aequum, nec ius colit.
Nigrior esse potest, nequior esse nequit.
Non vllum pilum viri boni habet. Cic.
Quid ei deest nisi res & virtus?
Quem fortuna nigrum finxit, hunc vniuersum aevum non potest candidum reddere. Aristot.
Virtutibus omnibus ianuam claudit, & vitijs aperit. Sen.

item.hi: He is ready to hang himselfe for woe.

list.item: Vna salus victis nullam sperare salutem. Virg.
Fit furor statim salutis propriae desperatio.

item.hi: H • is good neither in the egge, nor shel.

list.item: Malitiosus est bonus neque actu nec potentia. Aristot.
Non est laudandus ne in parentalibus quidem. Diog.

item.hi: He is neither absent without fault, nor present without excuse.

list.head: ¶ Destinie.

item.hi: A man can die but one maner of death.
Hee that is borne to bee hanged, shall neuer be drowned.
It is impossible to auoid destinie.

list.item: Ardente Troya, Priamus flammâ indiget. Sen.
Quod fatis decretum est, nemini evitare licet.
Fatale cui{que} quid fleat, quid gaudeat. Sen. Prou.
In fata media multi fugiendo ruunt. Sen.
Regitur fatis mortale genus. Sen. in Octau.
Nemo, non quasi sideratur ad projectam audaciam. Liu. lib. 11. cap. 10.

item.hi: All must be as God will.

list.item: Eveniunt non quae nos volumus, sed quae Deus decrevit.
Quo fata trahunt retrahunt{que} sequamur. Virg.
Fata seruant cursum irrevocabilem. Sen. lib. 2. nat. Quaest.

list.head: ¶ Diet.

item.hi: Vse reason, or moderation, and defie the Physitian.

list.item: Oportet esse vt vivas, non viuere vt edas. Arist. 2. Phys.
Continentiâ in victu valetudo conseruatur. Cic.
Fortiùs vt valeas, interdum parcior esto. Cato.

item.hi: Quicke • t meat, quicke at worke.

list.item: Sicion (seu bulbum) arrodens vxor lacernam texe.
Pinguis venter, tenuem non parit sensum. Eurip.

list.head: ¶ Difference, or distinction.

item.hi: There is a difference betweene staring and starke mad.

list.item: In rebus omnibus magis offendit nimium quàm parum. Cic.

item.hi: There is a difference betweene chalke and cheese.

list.item: Aliâ voce psittacus, aliâ coturnix loquitur.

item.hi: There is a difference betweene a being, and a well being, betwixt a life, and a welfare.
Better is better.

list.item: Vera vita non est, vbi vivitur infaeliciter.
Praestat non vivere, quam malè vivere.
Optima quidem aqua, sed praestat aurum.
Bene vivere, est melius quàm vivere.
Vivere me dices, salvum tamen esse negabis.

list.head: ¶ Discontentment.

item.hi: If the fountaines should runne wine, the people would not be content.
When we haue gold, wee are in feare: and when wee haue it not, wee are troubled.

list.item: Ita pleri{que} ingenio sumus, nostri nosmet paenitet. Ter.
Nemo sua sorte contentus est. Horat.
Nemo semet em • ndare quaerit, sed omnes caelites, &c. Sen. Epist. 107.
Optat ephippia bos piger, optat arare caballus. Horat.

item.hi: Farre folke fare best.
In farre Countries are golden crowes.
Hee esteemeth each mans birdes and iewels better then his owne.

list.item: Fertilior seges alieno semper in arvo. Ouid.
Amissa quae sunt maximè cunctis placent.

item.hi: One can hardly please all men.
It is hard for one man to amend all faults.
It is pitie that faire weather should doe any harme.
He that complaineth, is not content.

list.item: Iupiter suâ pluviâ omnibus non placet. Theog.
Multum deliro, si cui{que} placere requiro
Nemo semet emendare quaerit, omnes coelit es.
Quod nemo culpet, nullum reperias opus.

list.head: ¶ Discord.

item.hi: There is a iarre betweene them.
The Deuill hath cast a bone betwixt th • m.

list.item: Qualis lupis sortitò obtigit, discordia inter eos orta est. Horat.
Vbi dissensio ibi non est chorus.
Nulla spatia satis esse possunt discordibus.
Studia in contraria turpi dissidio rapitur. Mantuan.

item.hi: It may rhyme, but it will not accord.

list.item: Vxor hostis invita quae ad virum datur. Plaut.

item.hi: Hatred with friends is succour to foes.
Two dogges striue for a bone, and the third taketh the bone away.

list.item: Civili odio ad perniciem nihil efficacius.
Dissensio Ducum in bello, hostium est lucrum. Polyb. lib. 3.

list.head: ¶ Dissimulation.

item.hi: God in the hand, and the deuill in the heart.
Hee beareth fire in the one hand, and water in the other.
He doeth laugh and weepe with one breath.
He winketh with the one eye, and tooteth with the other, I will not trust him though he were my brother.

list.item: Ex eodem ore calidum & frigidum efflat. Aesop.
In os fert aliud, & aliud cogitat.
Saepe dissident ab animis vultus gratulantium.
Altera manu scabit, altera ferit. Greg.
Alterâ manu fert aquam, alterâ ignem. Plutarc.
Alterâ manu fert lapidem, alterâ panem ostentat. Plaut.

item.hi: Hee that cannot dissemble, knoweth not how to liue.

list.item: Consonus esto lupis cum quibus esse cupis.

item.hi: He playeth, See me, and see me not.
Hee would carry the matter inuisibly in a cloud.
He would not be seene in the matter.

list.item: Mittimus interdum quo nolumus ire, catellum.
Cum maximè fallit bonus vir videri vult.
Aliud palàm agere, aliud clam dedecet probos. Plin. lib. 4.

item.hi: Pretended holines is double iniquity.

list.item: Quod simile vero est, pessimum est mendacium. Quint. Decl. 11.

item.hi: All is not gold that glistereth.
Vice in vertues habite.
Faire words and full deedes deceiue many.

list.item: Multi qui boues stimulant, sed pauci aratores.

item.hi: When hee is sifted graine after graine, he prooueth but chaffe.

list.item: Non omnes qui habent cytharam sunt cytharaedi. Varro.
Non est in speculo res quam speculamur in illo.
Omne genus pestis vincit mens dissona verbis.
Omne quod est nitidum non imitatur ebur.
Quanto est ornatior, tanto est nequior.

item.hi: He playeth on both handes.

list.item: E lintre loquitur. Quint. lib. 2. cap. 3.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 : binis fidibus canit. Aristid.

item.hi: This faire weather will not hold.
Faire dayes in Ianuary, deceiue many in February.

list.item: Adhuc invitamur benignè, sed quod superest timemus. Cic.

list.head: ¶ Dogges.

item.hi: The dogge waggeth his tayle, not for you, but for your bread.

list.item: Nemo alterum nisi causa diligit sua. Lact. Dium. Histor. libr. 3. cap. 17.

item.hi: The dogge that killeth the wolfe, is at length killed by the wolfe.

list.item: Caedimus inque vicem praebemus terga sagittis.
Fortis in alium fortiorem incidit. Zenod.
Quem casus saepe praeterit, aliquando invenit.

item.hi: The barking of dogges driueth away theeues.

list.item: Bello & pace semper bonae canes. Plin. Hist. nat. lib. 8. c. 40.

item.hi: Fling the dogge a bone.
As good to haue a dogge fawne vpon him, as barke at him.

list.item: Apud causidicos ipsum silentium est venale. Cassiod.
Qui multum obfuit hostis, multum proderit amicus. Thucid.
Laedere qui potuit, prodesse aliquando valebit.
Offulae cibo sopitâ canis horrendi rabie. Apalei. 9.

item.hi: A man may easily finde a staffe to beat a dogge.

list.item: Nullum ad nocendum tempus angustum est malis.
Poenas dabit asinus, si vel mordit canem.
Cui quid vindicandum est, omnis optima illi occasio est.
Malefacere qui vult, nunquam non causam invenit. Syr.
Ecquis innocens esse potest, si accusasse sat est? Cic.
Inimicus nunquam caret praetextu criminis. Halicar. lib. 8. Antiq. Roman.

item.hi: Loue me, loue my dog, or hound.

list.item: Nobis nocet, qui nostris amicis nocet.
Rectè amicitias parentum transferas ad liberos.
Rex etiam violatur in ministris suis.
Duos amicos violat, violat qui alterum. Ouid. lib. 12. Metamor.

item.hi: A close biter.
A dog that biteth, and barketh not.
A dogge hath a day (namely of reuenge.)

list.item: Nihil tam firmum, cui non fit periculum ab invalido.
Ne contemne vllum hominem, quia nemo est, cui non sit hora.

item.hi: The dogge hath barked at me, but not bitten me.
Bragging mastiues seldome bite.
Wake not at euery dogges barke.

list.item: Canis ignavus lapidem mordet, eo qui jecit omisso.
Te minùs loquax inimicus offendat quàm tacitus. Sen. lib. de moralib.
Est oratio timidissimis audax. Sen. Epist. 7. lib. 3.

item.hi: All are not theeues that dogges barke at.

list.item: Innocentes allatrare pro nocentibus, canis est?
Damnat reum vita, ha • d accusatio Cic.
Difficilem oportet habere aurem ad crimina
Immerentes hospites saepe vexant canes. Hor.
Reus est, non qui accusatur, sed qui convincitur.
Falsum probrum vltra aures non penetrat. Aesch.

item.hi: A dogge to his vomit, and a sow to her wallowing in the mire.

list.item: — Ad mores natura recurrit damnatos. Iuve.
Omnia ficta citò ad naturam redeunt suam. Cic.

list.head: ¶ Doubting.

item.hi: He is amated and amazed.
At a bay.
He is at his wits end.
Hee knoweth not which way to turne him.
He is at a stand.

list.item: Levi momento huc & illuc impulsus. Ter.

In
aqua
vado haeret.
Quint.
Cic.

list.head: ¶ Drunkennesse.

item.hi: It is a sore fought field, where none escape vnkilled.

list.item: Non omne facinus in omni vita nascitur. Cic. pro Roscio Amerino.

item.hi: A Drunken fraie.

list.item: Saepe per vinum oriuntur dissidia Plautus.

item.hi: Malt is aboue the wheat with him.
Euer drunke, euer drie.
The more that a man drinketh, the more he may.

list.item: Quo plus sunt potae, plus sitiuntur aquae.
Parthi quo plus biberint, plus sitiunt.
Crescit indulgens sibi dirus hydrops. Hor.

item.hi: As drunken as an Ape.
As drunken as a Rat or Beggar.
He that hath care neither of body nor soule, may make himselfe drunken when he will.

list.item: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . i. Neque po • estatem corporis necanimi habet prop • er vinum. Dionys.

item.hi: A drunkard is not master of his owne soule.
When the
Ale
Wine
is in, the wit is out.

list.item:
Ebrietas prodit quod amat cor, siue
quod odit.
Absentem laedit, cum ebrio qui litigat.
Nihil aliud ebrietas, quàm voluntaria insania. Sen.
Magis soluta est post vinum licentia.
Vbi regnat ebrietas, ibi exulat ratio.

item.hi: He that killeth a man when he is drunken, hee shall be hangd when hee is sober.

list.item: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . i. Ebrius tyrannicum aliquod ingenium habet. Plato 9. libro de Repub.
Multa ebrij faciunt quibus sobrij crubescunt. Sen. epist. 1. lib. 12.
Ferè vinolentiam crudelitas sequitur. Sen. epist. 1. lib. 12.
Non est animus in sua potestate ebrietate deuinctus.

list.head: ¶ Education.

item.hi: HE is in the making and marring.

list.item: Adhuc sua messis in herba est. Ouid.
Proba est materies, si probum adhibeas artificem. Quint.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Plato 1. de de legibus. i. Arx disciplinae est recta educatio.

item.hi: With what liquor a vessell is first seasoned, It will long keepe the sent of it.
As children are vsed in youth, such will they be in old age.

list.item: Quo semel est imbuta recens seruabit odorem,
Nihil haeret tenacius quàm id, quod rudibus annis perceperimus. Sen.
Saliuā imbibit infantulus à qua siquādo discrepat, auersatur. Hier.

item.hi: He is better fed then taught.

list.item: Blanda patrum segnes facit indulgentia natos.
Corpus habet bene indutum, sed animum ignorantem.
Praestat non nasci, quàm male educari.

item.hi: Grace and good maners maketh a man.
It is better to bee vnborne then vntaught.

list.item: Recta institutio caput & arx virtutis. Aristot.
Haud facit partus matrem sed educatio.
